msgSnippet: If we eat our own dog food and follow the practices that JUnit is used to promote, than change should not be feared. ... Throw away my code, but never, never

Subject: RE: [junit] Re: How do I submit code which I think should be adde d to JUnit?
Date: Fri, 22 Jun 2001 08:11:25 -0500
MIME-Version: 1.0
X-Mailer: Internet Mail Service (5.5.2653.19)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
From: "Brekke, Jeff" <Jeff.Brekke@...>

If we 'eat our own dog food' and follow the practices that JUnit 
is used to promote, than change should not be feared.

-----------------------------------------------------------------
    Throw away my code, but never, never throw away my tests.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Jeffrey D. Brekke                                   Quad/Graphics
Jeff.Brekke@...                              http://www.qg.com
-----------------------------------------------------------------



> -----Original Message-----
> From: Johannes Link [mailto:john.link@...]
> Sent: Friday, June 22, 2001 3:47 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Re: How do I submit code which I think should be
> added to JUnit?
> 
> 
> > 2. JUnit as a political gesture celebrates the ability of 
> programmers
> > to test their own software. The code and tests must be held to a
> > higher standard, to demonstrate the techniques necessary to uphold
> > our end of the bargain.
> 
> I'd like to add two aspects:
> - JUnit should be the stable angle for the very unstable 
> projects we all
> have to do. Changing too much jeopardizes stableness.
> - When adding too much non-core functionality one quickly 
> looses focus of
> the core parts. Very often the extra functionality is not 
> exactly what I
> need in a specific situation, so I have to reimplement it 
> anyway. If the
> unneeded and unwanted part of a tool is prevailing many will 
> move towards
> starting from scratch with a new (small) framework. That's 
> why I'd rather
> have JUnit as a core with hooks to plug in additional 
> behaviour which is
> available in additional tools.
> 
> BTW, is the move to version 4 as described in
> http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?JunitNextRelease
> an "official" thing, i.e. promoted by Kent and Erich?
> 
> Johannes
> 
> 
> 
>

subject: RE: [junit] Re: How do I submit code which I think should be adde d to JUnit?
